en: Loading screen titles and hints
As Good as Dead

You would have your revenge on the Masked Man.
But first, he needed to know the depths of your anger.
And if you wrong us, do we not revenge ourselves?

You were surrounded with nowhere to run.
You were as good as dead.

The Cannibals had Old Man Murray.
Whether he lived or not, they would die.

The bank was full of cash, but security was tight, and there were demons ready to intervene, should the manager call for help.
Unless you recruited the madman detained in town, getting to the vault would be a challenge.

You approached the retired Demon's hideout with your mind on his money.
This wasn't going to be pretty.

The Masked Man might not die easily.
But you would make sure he paid for his sins.
CUSTOM SCENARIO UI
WANTED
$[%0] REWARD

for the murder of [%0] people
& $[%1] worth of damage
Objectives
Time to die. Take as many of them with you as you can
Kill everyone in town
still breathing)
Send a distress call over the telegraph to summon more enemies (Optional)
Find Masked Man and take your revenge
Go to Gin Mill and talk to Murray about Masked Man
Ask the locals about Old Man Murray
Attack the Cannibal Farm
Free Murray before he bleeds out. Or just kill everyone (Optional)
turns left)
Kill everyone
remaining)
Feast on the meat to regain strength (Optional)
Kill 100 people for an infernal reward (Optional)
Rob the Aspirton bank (Optional)
Kill or subdue the manager
Destroy the telegraph (Optional)
Open the jail door (Optional)
Get the safe key
Open the safe
Kill all hostiles to escape
Time until demons' arrival:
Raid the farm
Kill everyone
Ravage $65'000 worth of Masked Man's properties
Ravage $X worth of Masked Man's properties
Ravage $X worth of Masked Man's properties
Raid Masked Man's hideout
Raid the Demon's Hideout (Optional)
Kill the retired demon
Kill all the remaining hostiles
Kill the Masked Man
Kill the unmasked man
Main plot strategic events
After the fray

The stranger approached you again.

He said he knew the Masked Man's location, but that telling you would "spoil the sportsmanship of the hunt."

You didn't pay it much mind. You knew that if you took enough money from him, he'd find you.

The stranger asked if you'd met any of your enemy's enemies. Said he'd heard tell of an old man named Murray. Seems he ran the Gin Mill and had crossed the Masked Man somehow. Tracking him down might put you closer to your target.
Then the stranger made an ominous request. He said that if you took 100 lives he would reward you handsomely.
Fear rises
As the bounty on your head increased, people in the area wanted less and less to do with you. The shop owners raised prices 10 percent, hoping you'd take your business elsewhere.
The reward on your head attracted bounty hunters from far off places. Let 'em. It was their funeral. Still, anytime you went anywhere now, it seemed there were more enemies to contend with.
Terror spread through the land. Many of the shop owners just up and left town, closing their shops for good.
Damaging properties
You killed, burned and terrorized, but you still couldn't find much information about the Masked Man. Seems they still feared him more than you. Time to fix that.

Intimidation and destruction served you well. As you became more fearsome, the people you interrogated seemed to know more and more. You were moving up the chain. Still, the location of the Masked Man's hideout remained a secret.
Finally, you knew the Masked Man's location: his oil field.
Death toll

The stranger showed up right on cue. Congratulated you on a job well done.

Then he offered a boon of your choosing.
You asked for cash. Lots of it.
You asked for guns and equipment. And some more guns for good measure.
You asked for elite skills.
The stranger also gave you the location of the Masked Man's hideout.
Strategic screen status popup
Warren lost 25 Luck.
Exploration prompts
Murray Spirit Company

You arrived at Old Man Murray's gin mill to find the place ruined, deserted and covered in crates.

The upper floor office remained suspended but looked like it would fall apart any second. You figured you could grab one thing and get out. But should you get the money from the safe or the curious glass item on the desk?
You took the cash from the safe.
You took the glass item.

As you grabbed the item from the desk, the floor lurched and a low rumble heralded the office's imminent demise. You leaped from the room as it collapsed into rubble on the floor below.

You inspected the loot. Turned out to be just a strange old monocle.

As you grabbed the cash from the safe, the floor lurched and a low rumble heralded the office's imminent demise. You leaped from the room as it collapsed into rubble on the floor below.

You inspected the loot - not a bad chunk of tin.
Poaching Grounds

The forests in Indian country teemed with game, more than the natives could ever catch, let alone eat. Which made them easy pickings for poachers.

The ground was riddled with their traps. On a lucky day you could disarm them and steal the bait. On a bad day you'd catch a broken finger, a gashed hand, or worse.

Maybe it would be simpler just to stake out the traps and wait for the poachers to show. Nothing like stealing from a thief.
You tried to disarm a trap.
You decided to try to disable another trap.
There was always another trap waiting to be disarmed.
Your luck held. You deftly disarmed the trap and stole the bounty.
Pushing your luck, you disarmed another trap.
As you tried to pick the trap, lady luck showed you her bad side.
You set up an ambush for the poachers and settled in for a wait.

Finally the poachers showed. You took them out like clockwork, except for one.

At first he refused to talk, but some creative pain mismanagement took care of that. Once he knew you were serious, he told you Old Man Murray was alive, but had been captured. He said the Masked Man had left him with the rednecks living at Rancho Rojo, then paused for effect.

Seeing your puzzled face, the poacher added solemnly: "they eat people."
Gunsmith Shoppe

You entered the shop, a dozen of suspicious eyes burning holes in you.

A giant of a man presented himself as Mr. Dorias, the proprietor. He wanted you to know you were "personally" invited to shop in his place.
O. Dorias' gunsmith shop offered a decent selection of firearms. This time you attracted less unwanted attention.
Mr. Dorias asked if'n you needed anything else.
You browsed Dorias's wares.
Rumor had it Dorias was good with shotguns. You asked a few pointed questions.
You asked Dorias if he knew anything about what happened at Murray's Gin Mill.
You decided it was time to leave.
You left.
Dorias said he could install an additional barrel on your shotgun, for a price.
The gunsmith asked if you had any more shotguns that needed work.
You figured two barrels are better than one ([%0])
What's better than two barrels? Three barrels. ([%0])
Three barrels was good, but four was juuuuust right. ([%0])
You shook your head.
You left the shop.

The old gunsmith explained that if there was one thing that bothered the Masked Man, it was losing money. He'd started getting suspicious Murray was skimming money. And when the Masked Man got suspicious, he didn't waste time wondering what to do.
Elixir Trader’s
Jeremiah Benjamin Baker sold all kinds of cures, balms and ointments. If their smell was to be believed, most of them were a variation on bottled urine.
You browsed his shop anyway.
You decided not to waste any more time on the old charlatan.
You asked Baker about the cannibal farm.

The shopkeeper revealed the maneaters sometimes came to him looking for meat-tenderizers and exotic herbs.

If you wanted, he could send a letter of introduction, telling them you were one of them. That way you could approach them without raising the alarm.

Every favor has a price, though. He'd only do it if you helped him test his new potion.
You agreed to take a sip of his vile concoction.

A nauseating wave rushed through your body. Your face felt hot, then your entire body cramped up and you fell to the ground in agony. When it subsided, he apologized profusely, insisting you keep the rest as a make-good.

He'd send the letter immediately.
Hanged Slave

You encountered a hanged man, a runaway slave by the look of him. A voodoo talisman was tied around his wrist. You remembered your father grim face when he told you it was bad luck to touch a hanged man.
You decided to bury him.
Giving him a proper burial felt like the right the to do, but your personal satisfaction was the only profit you got from it.
You took the talisman.
As you took the talisman you felt a deep chill run down your spine.
Old John Kraimer’s Inn

Kraimer's dilapidated joint played host to a rowdy bunch of ugly-mugged drunkards.

And it was your lucky day. Sitting at the bar was one of the Masked Man's thugs that killed you.
Kraimer's dilapidated joint played host to a rowdy bunch of ugly-mugged drunkards.
You stabbed the thug in the back.
You got the cheapest drink they had. Just needed a little courage ([%0])
You got the best and strongest drink they had. Nothing like a little liquid courage ([%0])
You ordered the suspicous smelling stew ([%0])
You bought liquor.
You left while you were still standing.

You stabbed the thug in the back. As ladies screamed and men rose to their feet, you dragged him outside by his collar. After a little more persuasion, he spilled the beans on the Masked Man's locations and operations.
The thug gave you directions to the Masked Man's homestead and cattle pasture.
He said the Masked Man also owned an excavation site and an old sawmill, but was in the dark about the location of the Masked Man himself.

Begging you to spare his life, he told you of a gold transport waiting to be picked up from the bank in Aspirton. He warned you that the Masked Man had a deal with some demons to protect it. If they got a telegraph message, or the church bell tolled seven times, they'd swoop in like... well, like demons.

When he finished, you promised you wouldn't kill him. Then you slit his throat.

Drops of whiskey dripped through the holes in your face.
The liquor filled your mouth with fire and your heart with courage.

Drops of whiskey dripped through the holes in your face.
It was mighty fine hooch. You felt like you could take on the world.
The stew tasted funny and smelled funnier. You couldn't recognize the meat, and no one would tell you what it was. But it was that or seek vengeance on an empty stomach.

Old Man Murray looked like he was drinking to forget. While you were checking the Inn out, he just sat in the back, downing glass after glass of the worst poison they had, muttering about someone named Roberta.
You helped him out.
The ghost town of Hope
Rumor had it the whole town had died of plague in a single week. With the sickness in the air and the bodies on the ground, no one dared to loot the place.
The best thing about being undead? It gives you an iron stomach. You looted the husk of a town.
You found some loot, but there was something in the air. Your breath became heavier and slower.
You burned the place down and searched the remains.
You found some valuables in the ashes.

Suddenly, an old hag approached, squawking like a preacher. She said the city was a grave; but not all citizens were buried in it. Seven men were buried in the forest.

Six decent folk and one thief buried with his loot.

She said if you dug up the thief's grave, you'd be rich beyond measure.

Touch the wrong grave though, and you'd be cursed. Bad luck would haunt you, sickness would crush your bones and spirits would follow you forever.

She vanished, leaving you alone with the memorial marker.

Only part of the memorial was legible. All you could make out was:
Stephen Teague, a hard-working farmer
Romney Tate, a fair judge
Tony Sullivan, a magnificent cook
Donovan Byrnes, a brave miner
Sam Courtney, the finest blacksmith
The Southwest Mining Company excavation site.

Prospectors in the area had teamed up with Masked Man to form the Southwest Mining Company. You could collapse just the entrance for an immediate short-term effect. Or you could blow it up top to bottom to put it out of commission forever. That would take longer and there would be far greater risk of injury.
You collapsed the entrance.
With the mine entrance blocked, the mining operation stopped for a while, severely impacting the Masked Man's funds.
You blew up the entire mine.
You were injured in the explosion, but it was worth it. The mine was completely destroyed. The Masked Man would be furious when he heard about this.
Abandoned grave

Here lies Sam Courtney, a skilled [unreadable].

Sam had been found stabbed to death in his house, with no indication of struggle.
The investigation discovered that he'd been testing his new stab-proof jacket.
You dug it up.
You left.
You dug up the bones of an enormous man. He must have been the blacksmith. With him, you found a vest made of some kind of leather you hadn't seen before.
Mossy grave

The grave was covered in fresh moss, a pristine green carpet flecked with morning dew.

The only readable part of the epitaph was "...a fine merchant."
You dug up a skeleton wearing a merchant's finery, a vial of potion beside him. The card in his pocket read "Timothy McDonald."
Cracked grave

Someone had tried to dig this grave up, but left in a hurry.

A note was nailed to the cross: "Seeking this man's lawful heir. Contact me. - Romney Tate."
You dug up a thick-boned skeleton, by all appearances a cook. There was something stashed there... maybe it was still edible.
Lonely grave

This grave bore just a simple cross, and did not appear well-tended.

A name was carved on it: "Faryn Brygo"
There was nothing there, apart from the skeleton. You figured this must be the spot. As you dug deeper, your shovel thudded on a wooden chest. The thief's loot was yours.
Poor grave

This grave was poor as could be, though the meadow flowers around it meant he'd been loved.

You weren't sure why, but you have a feeling this was the grave of a farmer.
As goes the grave, so goes the man: poor. A name was sewn in the lining of his coat: Stephen Teague. The only other item present was a bottle of liquor.
Grimy grave

The grave was dirty and foul, filled with broken bottles and other debris.

The headstone read: Donovan Byrnes.
The skeleton was unremarkable, except for one solid gold tooth. Must have been a miner.
Mucky grave
This was a burial site, but not what you'd call a proper grave.
As expected, there were no fine clothes, gold or valuables here. But you did find a derringer. To your surprise, you also found a card saying: "Romney Tate, Judge."
Pinkerton grave
You came across a mass grave, labeled with the famous detective company's mark. Many an agent who had perished in the field lay there.
You found many valuables, but your karma felt like it'd been on a three day bender.
Indian totem of a despicable god

Beneath the totem lay a hoard of gold, precious stones and jewelry.
A screaming eagle carved into the totem spoke, posessed by a spiteful deity. It whispered that it wanted one of your companions. And that it would reward you greatly.
You sacrificed Old Man Murray. Sorry old pal.
You sacrificed Scrawny Kid. Sorry kid, it's just business.
You sacrificed Brandon Scott. You never liked the way he wore his breeches.
You sacrificed Childeater. He was bad business.
You tried to steal the valuables.
You left the totem.
You shot your companion in the back of the head. The vile god moaned in ecstasy and delivered your reward.
As you pocketed your blood money, the eagle suddenly attacked, damaging you severely.
X marks the spot
This had to be the spot
You started digging.
After an hour of digging, you hit a small iron chest. You shot the rusty padlock off and retrieved the small fortune residing inside.
You left before anyone saw you.
Old Sawmill
The old sawmill was no longer in use, its tall buildings fallen into wobbly disrepair. There would be lumberjack tools inside, but you didn't know if you should press your luck.
You turned reluctantly away.
The precarious building contained a saw.
You were successful in retrieving the tools, but it felt like your luck was running out.

In the dim light you spied a saw.

Unluckily, however, the moment you bent to pick it up, the entire building collapsed, crushing you in the rubble.
You left the sawmill.
Hermit Hut
The hut was filled with valuable items, gold and gems. Silent Jo, the hermit, was clearly off his rocker, but had an eye for quality goods. He asked if you could spare anything.
You shot the man, and looted his hut. Filthy hoarder. You were doing him a favor.
You gave the man what he asked for ([%0])
You gave the man what he asked for ([%0])
You gave the man what he asked for ([%0])

Pleased with the gift, he cackled to himself.

Then he asked for more.
You took what you judged to be a fair amount in valuables.
You couldn't tell if the Hermit was high or just crazy, but he told you of a spot where he'd found more treasure than he could carry. If you went there, you could retrieve the rest.
Big Tree
This was the tree the natives had been talking about. You were ready to take it down.
This was the tree the natives had been talking about. If you had the right tools you could cut it down.
With no tools to cut the tree down, you left.
You started cutting through the tree with the saw.

You sawed until your hands were covered in blisters.

Finally, in the center of the tree, you found a set of human bones. You took them to the natives who made a powerful charm from unlucky man's bones.
You walked away.
Water Tower

The water tower was the linchpin of Cannibal Farm.

You could have spilled the water to damage the Masked Man's property.
Or you could have poisoned the water to weaken the cannibals.

You returned to the water tower supplying Cannibal Farm.

You still needed to decide whether you should spill the water to damage the Masked Man's property or to poison the water to injure those who drank it.
You poured the poison into the water ([%0])
You smashed open the valve at the bottom of the tower, letting the water cascade out.
You left.

You dropped the poison into the water, then found a good spot to observe the results.

You saw, a couple of buckets being carried back to Cannibal Farm. A little while later you heard screaming. Then you noticed black smoke rising from the farm.

Were they burning bodies or roasting them?

You smiled as the contents of the tower spilled out and quickly disappeared into the parched earth.
This wouldn't be enough to prevent the Masked Man's men from working, but their hard times would become even harder.
Cannibal Farm

The farm looked innocent enough. But you knew better than to trust appearances.

The cannibals had heavy sentries at the entrances. You hadn't seen a trace of Murray yet. Chances are they had him locked away somewhere.
You returned to Cannibal Farm. Things looked normal. They didn't expect an attack.
You decided to go in guns blazing.
You entered the farm. If the elixir trader had kept his promise, the enemy wouldn't expect trouble.
You decided to return later.
After the fight, you noticed a bunch of farmhands high-tailing it into the fields. Horseback, you could have easily caught up with them.
You let them go.
You chased them down and shot every one.
As you dashed forward, you soon had your victims within range. Though they scattered, hid and crawled, none could escape your cleansing fury.

When the dust settled, you climbed the tall windmill to scout the region.

You could see a bustling and lively bar in the distance as well as a ghost town nearby. Just north of the farm, you spied a man dangling from a tree.
Grateful for his rescue, Murray told you everything he knew about the Masked Man.
Aspirton

After the recent unpleasant events, most of the community fled. The bank was the last secure location in town. It would be easier to raid Aspirton at night. Only a maniac would try to raid the bank in broad daylight.
You decided on a night raid.
You raided the town at under cover of darkness, setting houses on fire and firing into them at random. As expected, the few remaining survivors fled. By morning, Aspirton was completely deserted.
You robbed the bank.
While looting the town, you still encountered many people.
You killed any men who might put up a fight.
Without the men, the unprotected town would soon be deserted.
You killed everyone, regardless of age or gender.
You killed them all. Every single person. By your hand and by your device this settlement ceased to exist.
You decided to let them be.
Masked Man's hideout
This was the Masked Man's hideout. He had no doubt prepared a warm welcome.
You decided to attack immediately.
You decided not to attack just yet.
Masked Man's pastures

Cowboys tended herds across the fertile lands. The animals were owned by the Masked Man or one of his associates. The farmhands were just cheap labor, but their lives would still count toward your tally.
You decided to kill the horses.
You decided to kill the horses and hang the cowboys.

As soon as you showed your face, the cowboys fled in terror. You let them run as you methodically  slaughtered their horses, slitting their throats before shooting them in the head. Sleep tight, little horsies.

You rounded up the cowboys and tied them down. Then you killed the horses and hanged the farmhands on nearby trees. When you were finished, the landscape was peaceful again, just bathed in blood.

The Masked Man would hear about what you had done.
Masked Man's Homestead

It looked like the Masked Man was away. There were few clues, but you could still loot his house.

If you focused on the valuables, you knew the servants would get a chance to run.
If you focused on the servants, some would grab whatever they could and run off with it.
You took the valuables.
Slowly and carefully, you scouted the house. The service fled, while you collected all the shiny items and trinkets.
You took the valuables, enslaving whoever you could along the way.

They were good stock. With one hand you stole their valuables, with the other, you herded them into a room. There, you tied their hands and cuffed their necks to a chain. Then you marched them out to the forest and across the marshes for two days and two nights. On the third day you reached the slavers, who were more than happy to compensate you for your trouble. And your excellent merchandise.
You focused on killing the servants.
You walked from room to room, shooting everything that moved. While some managed to get away, often with the most valuable goods, you added many kills to your tally and found many trinkets of value.
You burned down the house with everything and everyone inside.

You circled the house, barring the exits and smashing every oil lamp you found. Undetected, you lit a cigarette, enjoying the tickle of smoke through the holes in your face. When it dwindled, you flicked it, a tiny coal arcing through pitch. A moment later the house was bright with merry flames. The screams of those being burned alive filled the night like a symphony, occasionally interrupted by suicidal gunshots.
You left the homestead behind.
Old acquaintance
As you walked through the forest, suddenly everything went silent. Not a bird chirped. You strained your ears, but heard nothing.

Suddenly you heard the crack of a shot, and a bullet tore your side. Seeking cover, you glanced back to see the blind gunman you robbed so long ago wearing a placid smile and scenting the air for another shot.

You plunged into the stream and let it carry you away. Hopefully the water would foil his fiendish nose.
You managed to get away.
Indian Camp
The natives lived in a small, infertile area that had been "given" to them by the occupying forces. They were accustomed to trading with palefaces, though most not as pale as you.
The natives could put any gunslinger back together with their rituals and herbal medicine if the price was right.

The natives could put any gunslinger back together with their rituals and herbal medicine if the price was right.

Except Old Man Murray. Murray was beyond fixing, they said. Many were convinced he'd been dead for years. You couldn't help seeing the sense in their theory.
You sought healing.
Warren needed healing ([%0])
Scrawny Kid needed healing ([%0])
Old Man Murray needed healing ([%0])
Brandon Scott needed healing ([%0])
Childeater needed healing ([%0])
The shaman chanted and, using a mix of herbs and oils, effected a cure.
You left the encampment.
You traded goods with the natives.
You sat by the fire and offered a bottle of whiskey to share ([%0])

You sat a few hours, drinking and smoking with the natives.

Around midnight, the real stories began to unwind. You heard tell of a sinister deity living in the forest. And a totem representing it not far away.

The natives told a tale of an old hermit who lived in a secluded hut. Word was he'd found a treasure of incredible value, but fearing the envy of others had kept to himself and was thus unable to enjoy his own riches.

Another campfire tale told of a man who took a nap in the shadow of a small tree. The smell of the sap kept him snoozing for weeks until the tree grew around him, burying him inside. Some nights, when the wind blew cold and there was no moon, they said you could hear him wailing beneath the bark.
You inquired about Old Man Murray.
The natives knew many old men, but no Murrays. They said the only white folk around those parts were the Masked Man's thugs, who poached from the nearby forest.
The Scrawny Kid

As you traveled down a lonesome road, the blood of your victims still smeared on your palms, a scrawny teenager stepped out of the bushes and accused you of killing his parents. You said you didn't rightly remember, but you'd killed so many people at that point, the odds were with him.
He didn't look like much of a threat, but from the pure hatred burning in his eyes you could tell that what he lacked in brawn, he made up with in determination.

His only problem was that he wanted to get them himself. That kid was hatred impersonated.
Bullied all his life, he was now getting payback, big time. He wanted to tag along.
As you travelled down a lonesome road, a scrawny teenager stepped out of the bushes. You's met him before - it was the twin who killed his brother. With a smirk, he called you a naive fool.
The kid said he appreciated your shooting skills and your killing talent. He wanted to tag along and learn your ways.
You let him join you.
You told him to get lost.
The scrawny kid joined you. You didn't yet realize that he would be the most vicious and sadistic being you would ever encounter. Apart from yourself, of course.
You just walked past, ignoring him. He bothered you down the trail a piece, and at one point set an ugly trap for you.
Well, shit.
Brandon Scott

As you travelled down a lonesome road, a trail of smoking ruins in your wake, an old man stepped onto the road ahead.

He knew you were going after the Masked Man.
He said that Masked Man had taken something he was after. He didn't approve of your methods, but he appreciated your effectiveness. He wanted to join you.
You let him join you.
You told him to get lost.
You'd soon learn the old man was the meanest cuss this region had ever seen. Until you showed up, that is.
You wondered if you'd ever see him again.
Fate Trader
You were quite confident you'd met the man before. He muttered a welcome.
You browsed his exceptional wares.
Demon's Hideout

You heard the story of a demon that once walked the earth with a gang. He amassed countless riches, then retired, hoarding his wealth in his hideout. It was said that he was exceptionally dangerous, but if you managed to kill him, all his loot would be yours.
This was the home of the retired demon gang leader.
You unleashed hell.
You would unleash hell later.
With the demon dead, all the riches were now yours.
